results.title: K-Rad Man
results.brief_description: A Mad Scientist creates the ultimate computer virus and locates a suitable test subject: K-Rad Man - to whom he can expose the computer virus and gauge its results.

results.title: Drat
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O'Neill
results.brief_description: A bunch of lab rats one night decide to break out and escape from their cages in the laboratory. One brain damaged rat, as a result of receiving shock-treatment, initially resists the call. This claymation reveals in its close yet another fiendish experiment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O’Neill

results.title: Mabo: The Life of an Island Man
results.creator_credit: Sharon Connolly, Trevor Graham, Denise Haslem and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Trevor Graham documented the only film record of the Mabo proceedings in 1989 in his film “Land Bilong islanders” and in the process established a friendship with Eddie Koiki Mabo. This film documents the extraordinary life of a man so passionate about his family and home that he fought an entire nation and its legal system. Sadly, he died five months before the High Court upheld his claim for “Native Title”. However he cemented a place in Australia’s history. This documentary won an AFI award in 1997.

results.title: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Australian Film Commission and Australia Council
results.brief_description: Peter Carey is one of Australia’s most talented writers. All four of his published works have won major literary awards. This film, takes a journey through his life and work and looks at the way he transforms his native country into a bizarre land of nightmares and surreal comedy. Throughout the film, an interview with Peter Carey is interwoven with lavish dramatisation. An intriguing and illuminating film about a remarkable writer.

results.title: Festival of the pig
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: Shows the villagers of New Guinea preparing for a feast in which pig is the chief item of food. Their elaborate costumes and a tribal dance are shown, while the sound track includes actual chants.

results.title: The Marist way
results.brief_description: Locally produced documentary promoting the virtues of the monastic life, and teaching methods practise by the Marist Order. The film details the rigorous regime of scholastic, spiritual and athletic training the Brothers apply to their words in boarding schools across Australia. In conclusion, it asks which of their charges will assume their monastic vocation.

results.title: Electric Visions
results.brief_description: A teenager at a video parlour plays a new video game. He climbs inside and tests his skills which lead him along the pathway of the development of electricity. Particular reference is made on the role of electricity in the development of Victoria.

results.title: The Telegram Man
results.creator_credit: Victoria Wharfe McIntyre, Ceinwen Berry and James Khehtie
results.brief_description: Multi-award-winning film ‘The Telegram Man’ poignantly depicts the human cost of war in its portrayal of relationships impacted by the vicissitudes of wartime. Featuring restrained but deeply emotional performances from some of Australia’s finest screen actors (Jack Thompson, Gary Sweet and Sigrid Thornton), this is a powerful film about loss, grief and duty.

results.title: Australian Designers show their talents [excerpt from Australian Diary No. 007]
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
We take a look back at some Australian designs from 1947. Woollen suits, sporty tennis outfits, debutantes gowns, plastic high-heeled shoes! hats and bridal wear are all paraded in this high-end extravaganza of Australian style.
Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection
